This
On
Week
List
Fiction
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) A Harvard scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
BIRTHRIGHT, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) An archaeologist on a dig in Maryland is forced to confront troubling questions about her past.
THE SECOND TIME AROUND, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) After the head of a medical research company goes missing, a magazine columnist finds herself the target of a sinister cabal.
FULL BLAST, by Janet Evanovich and Charlotte Hughes. (St. Martin's, $7.99.) A small-town newspaperwoman and a local playboy set out to discover who's behind the killings of really annoying people.
THE GUARDIAN, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $7.50.) While trying to choose between two suitors, a young widow realizes that her life is in danger.
THE RELUCTANT SUITOR, by Kathleen E. Woodiwiss. (Avon, $7.99.) In the early 19th century, an Englishwoman pines for a man to whom she has long been betrothed.
DIGITAL FORTRESS, by Dan Brown. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $14.95 and $7.99.) A cryptographer at the N.S.A. becomes enmeshed in murderous political intrigue after she breaks a mysterious code.
DECEPTION POINT, by Dan Brown. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) An intelligence analyst is sent to the Arctic on a special assignment by the White House.
THE SECRET LIFE OF BEES, by Sue Monk Kidd. (Penguin, $14.) In South Carolina in 1964, a teenage girl tries to discover the secret to her mother's past.
A MAN TO CALL MY OWN, by Johanna Lindsey. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) In the 1870's, twin sisters from New England become rivals for a Texas cowboy's affections.
CELESTE, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) After her twin brother dies, a girl's distraught mother forces her to dress and act like him.
KISS OF THE NIGHT, by Sherrilyn Kenyon. (St. Martin's, $6.99.) The latest novel in the Dark-Hunter series, featuring demigods, vampires and immortal viking warriors.
FATAL FLAW, by William Lashner. (HarperTorch, $7.50.) A Philadelphia lawyer agrees to represent a friend -- who he hopes will be convicted of murder.
LIFE OF PI, by Yann Martel. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) An allegory on the high seas, in which a teenage boy and a tiger are thrown together in a lifeboat.
THE WEDDING GAME, by Jane Feather. (Bantam, $6.99.) A professional matchmaker in early-20th-century London falls for one of her clients.

This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
READING LOLITA IN TEHRAN, by Azar Nafisi. (Random House, $13.95.) A memoir of a teacher's life in Iran, centered on a women's reading group.

THE DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY, by Erik Larson. (Vintage, $14.95.) The tale of a great architect (Daniel Hudson Burnham) and a serial killer (H. H. Holmes), who were linked by the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.
TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Warner, $6.99.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur; originally published in 1987.
MONEYBALL, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $13.95.) How the Oakland Athletics produce a successful team despite having one of the smallest payrolls.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Broadway, $11.95.) The author tells of his visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
KRAKATOA, by Simon Winchester. (Perennial/ HarperCollins, $13.95.) An account of the volcanic eruption in 1883.
TOUCHING THE VOID, by Joe Simpson. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) A mountain climber describes a disastrous accident in 1985.
RUNNING WITH SCISSORS, by Augusten Burroughs. (Picador, $14.) A memoir about a psychiatrist who went crazy while the author was in his care.
HOLY BLOOD, HOLY GRAIL, by Michael Baigent, Richard Leigh and Henry Lincoln. (Delta, $15; Dell, $7.99.) Extraordinary conclusions about Christ.
DRY, by Augusten Burroughs. (Picador, $14.) The author of ''Running With Scissors'' recalls his time working, and drinking, in the advertising industry.
*BRINGING DOWN THE HOUSE, by Ben Mezrich. (Free Press, $14.) How six M.I.T. students won more than $3 million at Las Vegas casinos.
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
LET FREEDOM RING, by Sean Hannity. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $14.95.) The commentator surveys domestic and foreign issues after Sept. 11.
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' '' recalls his life in foster homes. (+)
NICKEL AND DIMED, by Barbara Ehrenreich. (Metropolitan/Owl/Holt, $13.) What it was like to become a member of the working poor.
*SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Ballantine, $15.95 and $7.99.) The story of the horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with War Admiral.

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
THE PURPOSE-DRIVEN LIFE, by Rick Warren. (Zondervan, $19.99.) Finding the meaning of life through God. (+)
THE SOUTH BEACH DIET, by Arthur Agatston. (Rodale, $24.95.) A weight-loss plan designed by a Miami cardiologist. (+)
THE ULTIMATE WEIGHT SOLUTION, by Phil McGraw. (Free Press, $26.) Dr. Phil identifies ''seven keys'' to losing weight.
TRUMP: How to Get Rich, by Donald J. Trump with Meredith McIver. (Random House, $21.95.) Advice on business strategy and creating personal wealth.
THE PROPER CARE AND FEEDING OF HUSBANDS, by Laura C. Schlessinger. (Harper- Collins, $24.95.) Advice for women on how to treat spouses.

List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING, by Heidi Murkoff, Arlene Eisenberg and Sandee Hathaway. (Workman, $13.95.) For parents-to-be. (+)
*1,000 PLACES TO SEE BEFORE YOU DIE, by Patricia Schultz. (Workman, $18.95.) A reference book.
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Quill, $13.95; Avon, $7.99.) Losing weight. (+)
THE RED HAT SOCIETY, by Sue Ellen Cooper. (Warner, $12.95.) A guide to ''fun and friendship'' for women over 50.
*50 WAYS TO LOVE YOUR COUNTRY, by MoveOn. (Inner Ocean, $10.95.) A political group's handbook. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 10, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
